title: 114_hr5727
content: The "Preventing Iranian Destabilization of Iraq Act of 2016" imposes sanctions on terrorist organizations and foreign countries, including Iran, that threaten Iraq's peace or stability. The President and the Secretaries of State or Homeland Security must impose sanctions on foreign persons who have committed or pose a risk of committing acts of violence that threaten Iraq's peace, stability, economic reconstruction, political reform, or humanitarian assistance. The President and relevant Secretaries must impose sanctions on foreign persons who provide support for activities threatening Iraq's peace, stability, and humanitarian assistance. Sanctions include asset blocking under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act. The President and relevant Secretaries must impose sanctions on foreign persons under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act to block transactions involving property of individuals deemed a threat. Aliens meeting certain criteria may be ineligible for visas, admission, or parole. Aliens meeting specific criteria are inadmissible to the United States, ineligible for visas, admission, or parole, and cannot receive any benefits under the Immigration and Nationality Act. Consular officers can revoke current visas. Consular officers, the Secretary of State, or the Secretary of Homeland Security can revoke visas or entry documentation issued to aliens who meet certain criteria, regardless of when it was issued. The revocation takes immediate effect and cancels any other valid documentation in the alien's possession. The revocation of visas or entry documentation issued to aliens can take immediate effect and cancel any other valid documentation in the alien's possession. Sanctions imposed under certain conditions do not require a national emergency declaration and may result in penalties as outlined in the International Emergency Economic Powers Act. Exceptions exist for aliens to comply with the United Nations headquarters agreement. The President can waive sanctions for a foreign person on a case-by-case basis for up to 90 days if it's vital to national security interests. This waiver must be certified to congressional committees at least 15 days in advance. The President has the authority to terminate provisions and waivers after 3 years. The President can also exercise implementation and regulatory authority under specific acts for carrying out this section. Regulations must be promulgated within 90 days of enactment, with notification to Congress required 10 days prior. The President must notify Congress of proposed regulations and provisions of the Act being implemented. Definitions of "foreign person" and "United States person" are provided in the section. Title 31, Code of Federal Regulations, effective June 22, 2016, defines terms like "admitted" and "alien" according to the Immigration and Nationality Act. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate. "Knowingly" means that a person is aware of their conduct, circumstance, or result. The term "Government of Iraq," "person," and "property; property interest" are defined in Title 31, Code of Federal Regulations. This section will no longer be effective after January 1, 2022. SEC. 4. DETERMINATIONS WITH RESPECT TO CERTAIN IRANIAN PERSONS. The text chunk discusses the sense of Congress regarding Iran's acts of violence and the potential for further violence in Iraq. It also outlines the President's responsibility to determine if certain Iranian persons are engaging in threatening activities. These individuals include the Supreme Leader of Iran, the President of Iran, and members of the Council of Guardians and Expediency Council. The President is required to report to congressional committees on determinations made regarding Iranian individuals engaging in threatening activities, including key figures like the Supreme Leader of Iran and members of the Expediency Council and Revolutionary Guard Corps. The report must include reasons for determinations and may have a classified annex. The President must report to congressional committees on determinations regarding Iranian individuals engaging in threatening activities. If an Iranian person is found responsible for such activities, sanctions will be imposed. Appropriate congressional committees include those from the House of Representatives and the Senate. The President must report to congressional committees on determinations regarding Iranian individuals engaging in threatening activities in Iraq. If sanctions are imposed on an Iranian person found responsible for such activities. The President must report to congressional committees on Iranian activities in Iraq, including support for militias and political parties, referrals to UN sanctions committees, and the option to submit the report in classified form for national security reasons. The President must report to congressional committees on Iranian activities in Iraq, including support for militias and political parties, referrals to UN sanctions committees, and the option to submit the report in classified form for national security reasons. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate.
